Heishi,"2011-09-27T09:13:50.51Z","Nice set for VW bus collectors and large scale Lego set fans","

I had owned a 1975 Westfalia so I had to get this model.
column2: Very nice buy for fans of VWs and of larger Lego models.

column1: Pros
<ul><li>Nice sized model.&nbsp
column2:
Not to big nor to small
  • Well designed model. Doors, engine and roof open and close very smoothly.
  • Most of the kit is proportionate.
  • Not difficult or challenging to put together.
  • Very good detail.

column1: Cons

• No special VW pieces.
  • Not difficult or challenging to put together.
  • Front wheels don't steer.
I enjoyed building this model.
column2: Very happy with my purchase. I would have changed the color scheme.&nbsp
column3: It would of been nice to have an display card with information on the actual bus. All-in-all, a good buy for your money.&nbsp
column4:
I may modify it so the front wheels steer.

",TRUE,4,4,3,3,5

column1:
TechnicNick,"2011-10-01T18:19:09.083Z","Transporter of Delight","Sometimes you can tell when a Lego model has been designed by someone with a genuine knowledge and love of the subject. This is one of the few models that is as good as it can possibly be.

Whilst I take on board the previous reviewer's criticism of the lack of steering, I don't think such a feature is the point of this. It's all about the detail, inside and out.
column2: Building it is a singular joy. Take your time to appreciate the wealth of little details, especially inside. The fold out sofa/bed, the little cupboards, folding table, lava lamp (very groovy!), those dinky little curtains
column3:
the nicely detailed engine, dashboard and exterior fittings... all this and more add up to a truly delightful model.

It's a very playable model, with all the opening doors and configurable interior - if you've got any of those 1970s Homemaker figures, this is the right size for them.

Talking of size, it's not that big considering the piece count and price - what it is, is a little jewel to stand proudly on your display set-up, preferably with some happy 1970s figs grooving it up '60s style!

I don't even mind the stickers - there's only a few, one of which is a banner displayed in the rear side window
column4: Make Lego Models Not War! I couldn't agree more.",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

column1:
Monty,"2011-10-25T01:59:53.453Z","Pretty ""Splitty""","

I haven’t bought a large set for a while now, but when I saw the camper was to be released I was as enthusiastic about it as everyone else. I made it over the weekend and have to say I was not disappointed.
column2: It is the first set I have bought where the instruction books (2 here) and the stickers have come in a plastic bag with a cardboard insert to stop them getting damaged. Many times in the past I have opened boxes to find creased instruction booklets and sticker sheets – so well done Lego. The box itself is of the type where it can be closed using a little tag and slot and can be kept for future use.
column3: There are numerous plastic bags not numbered so it is a case of tip them all out and look around for your parts. The build is not particularly complex, but it can get a bit fiddly when you are trying to hold several parts together that open or move, and the side with the opening doors is a bit flimsy. In this respect it would be easier if the front door hinges were not quite so loose – I think it has something to do with the colour as in when I have used them in black I recall them being stiffer.
column4: The one part of the design I never liked from the pre-release publicity shots was the rear grilles/louvres which Lego did using ladder bricks which protrude from the body side. They should be set into the body side and as such flush with it. I think the way Lego has done them looks cheap and nasty, and it lets down an otherwise excellent looking model. Before building, I worked out a way to produce a more authentic look with grille bricks, which necessarily meant modifying that part of the build as I went along with extra parts from the spares box, but I think it looks much better. Perhaps Lego could have done it this way as it did not use that many parts, and for a set rated 16+ what I did was not that complicated for an experienced builder.
column5: I also made my build more complicated by deciding to do mine as a U.K. right hand drive version. This is a mirror image of the set as it comes (except for the fuel filler) and I actually used a mirror to look at the instructions as it made it easier to work out.
column6: It slowed the build a little, having to remember the step 1,2,3... order was also reversed in the mirror. &nbsp
column7: Once I was back on the components that weren’t handed like the roof, speed picked up once more.
column8: The interior is wonderful with its working rear seat which turns into a bed. I have to say as an Aston Villa fan I wholeheartedly approve of the claret and blue colour scheme of the seats. There is a sink with cupboard underneath, and a closet with mirror door as well as a folding table and shelves on the inside of the opening side door. There is a picture, a 1960s lava lamp, a plant, a brush and a frying pan (no cooker?) and the much publicised “build Lego” T shirt. The curtains provided fit quite well and provide that finishing touch.
column9: On the exterior all doors open as does the engine compartment cover which reveals a representation of the VW engine – which is done quite well. The windscreen opens too, as does the rear door/window. The expanding roof requires you to build a scissor raising table and then wrap the supplied cloth around it and put bricks and plates on top and around to hide it when folded down. It works really well – just the right amount of stiffness. As per the instructions, the roof is designed to come off, but I think it needs a few
column10: more studs rather than plates to give the roof more to hang on to as it comes off too easily as built. There are hardly any studs on the non-doors side. With all these working features it has maximum playability as well as good looks.

column1: There are stickers for the split screen windscreen bar as well as for the sides of the rear windows. They are also necessary for the interior picture and the T - shirt. There are silver mirror finish stickers for the front VW logo and the mirror on the closet door.

Not sure if the brick used for the front wheel arches is a new element – I have not come across it before - it seems to have a reduced curve which fits the wheels really well. For those who would have preferred working steering it is difficult to see how it could be incorporated, as there is not much clearance, but if it can be done that would make it even better. I enjoy the challenge of “improving” or customising sets as well as building MOCs. My final customisations involved detailing the engine and the cab and adding
column3: mirror tp the passenger side.

column1: I wanted an authentic
column3: so I made MOC stickers for 1966 ""D"" reg number plates with matching&nbsp
column6: There is also a GB sticker and a VW Service Sticker on the rear window. The final touch was to replace the inside picture with one of my own beach photos shrunk to fit,&nbsp
column11: World Cup Willie"" as 1966 was the year England hosted and won the tournament.
column12: For once I was entirely satisfied with the price at 80 GBP. I thought it was more than value for money compared to other large sets I have bought in the past.
column13: The Lego designer (guy in the YouTube video?) has done a brilliant job here – very clever and has used techniques for one or two things I don’t think I would have thought of. On all counts, this set merits a maximum score and is now up there with the Fokker DR1 and Technic Tow Truck as one of my all time favourite Lego models.
column15: Brickshelf page if you want to look.

column1:
Buckbrick,"2011-10-13T05:19:06.723Z","Wow what a set!","

When the preliminary pics of this set was leaked, as with many, I found it unappealing. But after Lego put out the official pics and a promo video of it, it immediately shot to the top of my
column3: list. It may well possibly be the most desireable set all year.

column1: Model:

The van looks gorgeous. The designer did a great job in translating the many curves of the van into brick elements that were great fun to build, entirely unlike the previous VW model, the Beetle that was mainly a studs-on-top build. The T1 is in red, but I was kinda hoping that it would be in a
column2: vermillion colour, much like the actual vehicle.

column1: I guess the interior is the main highlight of the vehicle for most. I for one found it a little overboard at times. You get a folding table, 2 seats (one folds down as a bed), lava lamp, the amusing T-shirt, a sink and mirror, chequered floorboard...
column2: The build was definitely fun: it's like a modular building&nbsp
column3: on wheels!

column1: Build:

It took me an afternoon to put the 1332 pieces together, so it wasn't a tough build. It was definitely great fun! I'm in awe of how many items that can be shoehorned into a set this size. Lots of red and white and miscellaneous hard to find pieces.
Stickers!

Love 'em or hate 'em, they do finish the look very well and I do apply them. You get the VW emblem printed in shiny sticker, along with the mirror sticker. My only peeve is the 3 trans window sticker pieces that I left out.
Conclusion:
Really you ought to be running out and buy it now. It will go down in Lego history as one of the
column2: classic sets along the same line as the Emerald Night - both elegant and great models.&nbsp
column3: I love the size of the set, and you can display it almost anywhere. I got it for 210SGD and it's definitely worth every penny.

column1: Pics!

",TRUE,5,5,5,4,4
DrOrrery,"2011-12-29T08:02:49.76Z","It's Lego Jim, but not as we know it","
column2: "">I got this for Christmas and stayed up til midnight doing it after my youngest had gone to bed. &nbsp
column3: It is an undeniably impressive piece, but I find myself with mixed feelings about it, which I will hopefully get across in this review.

column1:
Box/Instructions

Hooray for instructions wrapped against cardboard!
column2: And a small cheer for sticker sheets wrapped against cardboard as well. &nbsp
column3: Can't complain too much about the stickers in this one, given how unique they are.

column1:
Parts

Given the accuracy of the look that has been achieved here, there are actually very few special parts used for the majority of the build.
column2: Those that have are generally to do with the interior details, like the green goblet, T-shirt piece and the taps.

column1:
The build

The build itself was both straight forward and really interesting.
column2: The model starts from the floor and builds up, as you might expect. &nbsp
column3: Nothing too difficult, but lots of clever details for allowing sideways curves, like the bumpers and side panels, and lots of interior detail. &nbsp
column4: The moving seat that flattens out into a bed is actually held by two android arms. &nbsp
column5: That's all that is keeping it connected to the model, and yet it is very stable in both the upright and flattened position. &nbsp
column6: Also, lots of opening and closing parts, like the rear engine compartment, the doors and the rear window. &nbsp
column7: And of course, the cloth pop-up roof. &nbsp
column8: I had no idea how the designer had done this, but it turned out to be brilliantly simply and elegant, and it works incredibly well. &nbsp
column9: About the last thing that's put on are the rear wheel arches that come down slightly over the top of the wheel, and even this detail is simple but beautifully done (especially since one of them contains the petrol cap).

column1:
The completed model

First off, the completed model looks astounding.
column2: The curves are incredible, and the only surface with studs on is the roof. &nbsp
column3: I'm glad they left them there, because otherwise it would be fairly easy to mistake it for a large die-cast model on first glance. &nbsp
column5: As a model and an attempt at realism, this is a triumph. &nbsp
column6: I can't think of anything Lego has done that is even in the same league as this. &nbsp
column7: But the flip side to this is, to me, after building it, it doesn't really feel like Lego anymore. &nbsp
column8: With a build of similar size, like say the recent Millennium Falcon, I spend ages marveling at all the great details done in Lego and thinking about ways I might want to modify it, and actually playing with it. &nbsp
column9: With this model, I spent ages looking at the details thinking ""wow, did Volkswagen actually do that? &nbsp
column10: What a great thing to have in a van."" &nbsp
column11:
My focus was really more on how cool the actual van was rather than the Lego I'd used to make it, because, and I know this sounds a little strange, it's such a good model that it almost stops being Lego.

Which leads to the one gripe I have about it, it's not particularly robust.
column12: Actually, most of it is incredibly robust, but some sections, especially the removable roof, doors and bumpers, I find finicky and easily broken or hard to get to fit properly. &nbsp
column13: This can make it quite difficult to pick up, but again, that's partly because this is intended really to be made and then kept on a shelf. &nbsp
column14: Now, that's not a complaint, any more than one would complain that the new Super Star Destroyer isn't particularly swooshable, but it is the first Lego model I've owned where that is true.

column1:
Summary

The bottom line is this is an amazing set, but I think this set is a different beast to most sets out there, and I think how much you like it will be affected by that.
column2: If you like a great build, this has it in spades. &nbsp
column3: If you want to be amazed by how good a model can look, ditto. &nbsp
column4: But if you actually like playing with Lego, I'm not sure this one's for you.",TRUE,4,4,5,2,4

column1:
Kristska,"2011-10-10T16:41:11.773Z","Nice little car...","

[img]http://cache.lego.com/images/shop/prod/10220-0000-xx-12-1.jpg[/img]

The box shines as soon as you look at it, a camper van in white and red.

One can see clearly that there is a car to make and known parts show up while you build. I recommend this kit to those who are patient, and one should not give it to the far too young. This is more a &quot
column3: object and not a toy. Although LEGO really is a toy ...

column1: Thanks to LEGO that they made this kit so that you can dream back to the old days ...&hellip

Looks nice
Summary
Nice little car to build...

,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 Duq","2012-01-04T17:09:42.153Z","Nothing is perfect but this comes pretty close!","

In 2008 Lego released set 10187, the iconic Volkswagen Beetle. This time we're treated to it's cousin, the camper van. It's slightly smaller than the Beetle but it makes up for that in details.

Box/Instructions

There's usually not much to say about a box but this is one is different. The front shows the model against a real life background image of the Swiss Alps. On the back of the box is the same backdrop with a number of snapshots of details of the model as well as a picture of the original van.

There are two instruction books. They come in a plastic bag with a cardboard backing to keep them flat.

The build

This is an interesting model to build because it is so full of details. It starts with a simple chassis but soon you're adding interior details, the engine and then the outside of the car.

The box says '16+' and while I think that may be a little high this is clearly not a set for children to build. There are no numbered bags so at the start you have well over a thousand pieces on the table in front of you.

Having said that, while it's a complicated model the instructions are excellent so anyone with some experience building larger sets (like Star Wars UCS, Modular buildings or Diagon Alley) should be able to build this camper van.
<h4 style=""border-style: initial
column3:
"">Parts

With over 1300 parts it's impossible to mention them all here
column4:
obviously there's a lot of red and white including red plate and brick hinges. The seats are covered in dark red and medium blue tiles and there is some tan in the interior. There are a few parts worth highlighting:

The curtains are made of fabric and while I had my reservations about this when I first heard about the set they do look the part. There is another piece of fabric for the extending roof.

There are a few stickers
column5:
the number plates, the mirror, the VW logo, the T-shirt and the windscreen and rear window. More on them later.

There's a present from the designer: two transparent headlight bricks are used in a completely invisible spot in the engine. Keep two grey or black headlight bricks handy when you build the van
column6:
-)

In fairness though, who cares about the parts in the set? Nobody is going to buy this as a parts pack: this is a set to build and display for a long time.

The completed model

The finished product is just beautiful. The red and white colour scheme is both historically correct and striking. The black stripe works as an accent between the colours and also helps to create the characteristic V on the front.

There are so many details I won't mention them all here. All the doors open to show the interior and you can take the roof off for a better view.

As I said in the title nothing is perfect. There are a few details that let the side down.

There are stickers in the set but for some reason the speedo is represented with the familiar round clock tile. Why couldn't that be a sticker of an accurate speedo?

There is a sticker for the split windscreen and two more for the back window. These are transparent stickers the size of the panel they go on. Or at least, nearly. There's no need for them to be as wide as the panel because all they do is 'paint' a 2mm wide stripe. The sticker however is not as tall as the panel, leaving a little gap.

I don't think those stickers are necessary on the rear window and I wonder if there really wasn't an alternative for the windscreen. Still, if you're doing it with sticker then at least make them big enough.

The sticker on the T-shirt says ""Make Lego models not war"". I'm sure that's correct according to the official guidelines for the use of the word Lego, but I would have preferred ""Make Lego not war"".

The air vents at the back are done with ladders. I wonder if grille bricks wouldn't look better.

But those are tiny details. They don't take away from the overall look and the abundance of details.

column1:
Summary

This is obviously a model to display and with over 1300 parts for €99,99 it's pretty good value too. You could play with it although it's not easy to ride on the living room carpet with no steering and wheels fixed on axles.

Whether you like Lego, Volkswagens or cars in general, this set is a must have. It's definitely one of the best ever Lego sets in my books.

",TRUE,5,5,5,4,5

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,4,5 darthdc","2014-03-30T20:14:33.507Z","Another classic vehicle - Lego-ised.","

Well, I'
column2: m no fan of the VW Camper as a rule, but this is one great looking set. I picked it up from John Lewis (I didn&#39
column3: t know that it could be bought outside Lego.com) for the RRP of &pound
column4: 79.99, and I admit that it not bad value for the price.

column1: The box is quite large: approx 19"
column3: x 2.5&quot
column4: and unusually for a Lego box, resealable in cereal box fashion. Apart from photos showing various details of the model, it also has a few (though not enough) photos of the real vehicle.

column1: The instructions are divided across 2 books, which come in a plastic bag, along with the 2 small sticker sheets, and a large piece of card to keep them flat.

The pieces (1334 of them, plus the usual spares) comprise of mostly small pieces. The habit of making some pieces only available in certain colours is once again in play, with areas where a 2x4 plate could be used, instead having 2 2x2 plates side by side. There is one area where a 1x1 brick and a 1x2 brick are placed side by side rather than a 1x3 brick, despite the latter being used in this set.

One of the things that make this set special, is the fabric parts. 6 identical curtain pieces which are brightly coloured in red, green and yellow. Then there is the large orange curtain that fits around the pop up roof. All are attached to the model with 1x2 plates with bars.
So, while the model has no figures (the old technic figures would seem a good size), this model is purely for display purposes.

The build is fairly straight forward, with SNOT techniques on the window frames especially. The roof can be tricky though, especially the end sections. The pieces on the back are not held in place well, and when placing the roof on the vehicle, they can break off. The pop up roof section uses a scissor mechanism, which works well.
Alas, there are stickers, though not too many. All fit onto individual bricks, which is good, but the snag are those that are placed on the window pieces. You'
column2: re going to get fingerprints on those pieces.

column1: The hub caps (3M wide dishes) ares held in place using 2 1x1 round studs, though I thought axels with stud ends would have been the better option.

Overall, its a good model. The one seat folds down to form part of a bed, and the table folds down too. All doors open, including the engine compartment, rear window and front windscreen. The only thing it lacks are suitcases or surfboards to place in the luggage rack.
Just like another reviewer, I'
column2: ve converted it to right hand drive.

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,4,5
av8r1973","2012-12-17T21:54:46.813Z","Excellent tribute to a worldwide classic!!","We skipped the Beetle. &nbsp
column2: Not sure why - perhaps it didn't appeal to us. &nbsp
column3: This screamed, ""Buy ME!"" &nbsp
column4: We anticipated its release, watched the designer interview and again anticipated shipment from LEGO. &nbsp
column5: It came in and the box was drooled on for several nights (needed to wait for the kids to go to sleep and for us not to be tired). &nbsp
column7: Many closeups that look like they were taken from a Westfalia brochure. &nbsp
column8:
I'd like to camp in it!

The build was complex with some very thoughtful SNOT building.
column9: As you're building it, you don't know exactly what it is you're putting together until that ""A-HA"" moment arrives. &nbsp
column10: Then you realize it was crafty building with clever instructions that left you in the dark. &nbsp
column11:
Very cool.

Feature-wise, the camper is not lacking.
column13: Side doors open - both of them. &nbsp
column14: Front windshield swings up for the original 2-60 air-conditioning. &nbsp
column15: Rear hatch opens to reveal an incredibly well-thought-out engine bay. &nbsp
column16: Just plain old elements put together to create a masterpiece. &nbsp
column17: The roof panel pops up for the camper version. &nbsp
column18: Of course, all four wheels turn, too. &nbsp
column19: Playability doesn't stop on the outside, either. &nbsp
column20: Inside, the dinette folds into a bed, as does the rear couch. &nbsp
column21:
Top that off with some artwork, curtains and tableware, and you've got a very detailed interior.

We let a friend's kid play with this and he just about destroyed it.
column22: Front and rear were in many pieces when he left (alive, by the way). &nbsp
column23:
Ten minutes later, I had it back together without the aid of the manual because it was that intuitive.

The entire kit was brilliantly designed and packaged.
column24: This model sits out in plain view in our formal room because it looks that good. &nbsp
column25: It doesn't look like a toy. &nbsp

column1:
nollynixon,"2012-03-22T05:12:22.403Z","I had a smile on my face the whole time...","It's hard to believe that I am now considered an, ""Adult fan of Lego."" But, I'm 32 years old and I now have to face the brutal truth. I've recently rediscovered my youth and the undeniable force of the Lego set.

I had so much fun building this set! I never thought twice about the Volkswagon T1 Camper until I saw it in my local Lego store. Now, I wouldn't mind owning the real thing! That's how good this set is. I'm pretty sure I had a smile on my face the whole time I was building it.

The only ""Con"" I have is that it took me just two nights to build. But, once I got started, I couldn't stop! So, I highly recommend this set and can guarantee you that it is worth $120.


",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

mattiasnordqvist,"2012-04-21T11:45:01.847Z","Awesome","My comeback set. My Dark Ages have passed. I'm now a Lego fan again.

Right after I bought this I felt like it was a waste of money. I didn't really believe I would enjoy this, but I was wrong. So wrong. This set is amazing, has a lot of detail, is pleasing to the eye. It has a nice set of features, like the foldable chair and the smooth roof.

I had a wow-feeling like three or four times when I build this set. I was very impressed by the implementation of air-vent at the roof. The side panels are also created using some pieces I've never seen before. Very nice. The hatch in the back, which can be opened to show the engine just feels so great to open and close, which I guess I've done like 50 times.

Being probably around ten years since my last set, I noticed a few things. There was no plastic to host the pieces inside the box. Just plastic bags floating around, so I had to pour all the pieces out on the table. Also, the pieces feel lighter today than they did last time. It also seems like the colours shift in nuances. I have never noticed this in my old collection. This gave me an overall feel that Lego is sacrificing quality for price, but I guess they have to, so that's ok.

Now, this set made me think of buying more sets. After once again realizing that Lego is awesome, I no longer think a few hundred bucks is too much for a modular building or another large scale model. :)
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

I purchased it ahead of the other 2013 exclusive sets.&nbsp
column22: >This is a must have set for every Volkswagen fan and for people who grew up in the 60's. This is an impressive recreation of the iconic Volkswagen Camper Van from the 1960's, this is an iconic and popular LEGO set as its one of LEGO's best seller.
column42: >This set contains four unique pieces: Tr. Yellow Plate 1X1 W/Tooth, Pc used as interior lights in the Camper Van. Curtain Vw ""No. 1"" is a brand new element used as 6 curtains in the Camper Van. Bright Orange Pop Up Roof is another brand new element used for the Pop-Top. Brick Yellow Frame F. Train Window 1X2X3 only appears in this set in this colour.
column57: >This set does not include any minifigures. This set is not intended for play and is only a display set with features like the actual Camper Van.
column72: >This set is not really made to play, it does have features like: opening doors (4), Opening engine door which reveals the realistic engine design, opening rear window, opening safari windows, the iconic ""V"" front with the Volkswagen logo, front and rear licence plates, Gas tank, front and rear lights, Pop-Top, luggage rack, fold down table, seats can be changed into a bed, sink, lava lamp, plant, photo, ""Make LEGO Models Not War"" t-shirt, drivers area details.
column87: >This set contains fifteen unnumbered bags. The two instruction booklets are thick which come in a cardboard sleeve to keep them straight with the stickers.
column92: >The build is very enjoyable and not too repetitive starting at the bottom and working your way up, the stickers where the only down side to the build which stressed me out. The build is very study when complete.
column107: >This retails for £79.99 in the UK and contains 1334 pieces. Volkswagen fans will really appreciate this model, however people who are not familiar may not be drawn to this set other than it is a bright vehicle which stands out from other Lego models on my shelve. It delivers a different build experience, compared to your average set as its aimed towards adults.
column122: >Volkswagen is iconic and can be recognised all over the world as this will be a fine addition to your collection and will make a great collector’s item.
column137: >This set is available at Lego Stores and http://shop.lego.com/ and other selected retailers.
column152: >The box is very classic and 60's style, with snapshots of features on the Camper Van.&nbsp
column168: >This will do very well as a long term potential as for adults who are from the Volkswagen Community.
column183: >Yes, this It is a great collector’s item and display piece with minor flaws like:
column191: >Pop-Top is uneven, gaps in some areas, the stickers were a real pain and could have been printed, grill lines are suppose to be inside the van, engine door sticks out, small kitchen needs to be bigger, no&nbsp
column193: axle (Even the wheel doesn't move) It could of have brick built luggage
column208: >Overall this set it is a must have set for every Volkswagen fan. If you’re a Lego collector of cars this will also be a unique and it will stand out from other Lego cars of this scale. This set has four unique pieces. Is it worth the money: for “Volkswagen” fans is a must buy. This set is a best seller so get you hands on it when you can.

column1:
captainjack10,"2012-12-26T17:08:07.027Z","Great Display Model","

I purchased this set as a Christmas present for myself in 2011. I've always ben a fan of both Lego and VW Camper Vans so when I saw this set I had to have it.

Box/Instructions

The box shows the completed model on a photographic background as well as interior shots of the model on the rear. One part of the box I particularly liked was the inclusion of a photograph of the original VW Camper Van alongside shots of the model.

The instructions were clear, simple and easy to follow.

The build

This set has 1332 pieces and took me around 8 hours to build over a period of 4 days. The majority of the build was relatively simple however a couple of areas proved more tricky than others. In particular the front section of the roof, which I rebuilt numerous times thinking I had gone wrong somewhere, can be rather unstable. The roof still becomes detached now when I pick the model up.

The completed model

The completed model is an absolute stunner. Everyone who has seen the build has said how accurate the model is and how they didn't realise Lego made such intricate designs. The small details such as the interior decoration and the moving roof piece make the model that much more special.
column2: I'd say this model is more of a display piece than a model to play with. My younger brother (age 4) always wants to play with it however as others have mentioned it usually ends up falling apart, particularly on the roof as previously mentioned.

column1:
Summary

Overall an amazing model with great details that looks great out on display.

",TRUE,4,5,5,3,5

matrix_7000,"2020-03-19T18:48:13.377Z","Nice set for collections","

This great set is very nice and it will fit perfectly in your collection. This set is also available in mini scale.
One little problem, the roof system is not the best that Lego has ever made.

,TRUE,4,4,4,4,5 Wom","2016-01-10T12:54:28.42Z","Vintage camper with sex appeal","

This is the set which brought a lot of people back from their dark ages. And it'
column2: s also a set which Lego is producing for a very long time, without losing any interest form the public it seems. What makes this VW T1 camper so desirable?&nbsp

column1: Box/Instructions
Lego nailed it with the vibe on the cover art. Although I normally the more sober approach with cover art, it'
column2: s the background which gives the T1 room to shine. With it&#39
column3: s nice red and white color scheme the T1 really pops out.&nbsp

column1: Also the displayed interior shots add the the excitement you get when seeing the box. You basically can'
column2: t wait to get your hands on all the details they show off.&nbsp

column1: The instructions are clear and give a bit of a modular feeling during the build. You really construct one part of the model which you see growing in front of you.
Parts

There are some unique parts which come with this set. The one whch stands out for me is the orange fabric used to simulate the raised roof. They construction used is clever and the orange really stands out. The period-correct orange works like a charm in adding detail to the model.
Other
column2: parts worth mentioning are the curtains. Dripping with 70&#39
column3: s design they really add to the charm of the T1. This to me is smart use of unique parts, as they add to the attractiveness of the set. The main parts used are the ones you already know, often being used in a smart way.&nbsp

column1: The build
For a lot of people this is a set they bought after a long absence at
column2: the Lego universe. Keeping that in mind this build is a good advertisement for Lego. With little repetitiveness&nbsp
column3: and a modular approach to building the complete camper this is an enjoyable build to say the least.&nbsp

column1: The interior is very detailed, offering some really smart techniques for building small appliances. Combined with the more larger structure for the exterior this build offers all parts of the Lego building trade.
The completed model
Wow! This is really a good looking model. The distinctive
column2: details are captured nicely and everybody will recognize&nbsp
column3: this model directly. With the removable roof and various doors an compartments which can be opened, there are a lot of options to display this T1.&nbsp

column1: I must admit that the finished build is not very suitable for playing. The roof comes off easily and the doors are a bit hard to align one closed. People with OCD will have a hard time with adjusting the doors and the hinges used.

For adult hands the interior is also a bit small, making it a bit harder to show off the folding bench and other details. But these are small remarks, considering the overall look and feel of this model.
Overall opinion

Very attractive set which features one of the most iconic vehicles around. It deserves to be displayed at a nice place in your house. Playability is not that great, but the VW T1 offers more than enough to keep you entertained for a long time!

,TRUE,5,5,5,4,4 pinz","2017-12-29T23:56:46.89Z","Pure nostalgia but no fun to build","

The T1 a.k.a. Bully is one of the most iconic vehicles from Volkswagen. It was also a icon for the movement in the late 60'
column3: s and has the well recognizable&nbsp
column4: sound of the engine from VW Beetle. To get a real one in good condition or renovated is a hard, and if you find one, it is probaly&nbsp
column5: very expensive. So the Lego-set is maybe the better choice.

column1: All the design-features of this car
column2: are somehow included in this model, besides the sound. It models the shape of the chassis very good, also the details, like the pop-up roof or the lava-lamp and the T-shirt&nbsp
column3: are very nice. Also a nice idea of an engine is in and the split windshield was considered.

column1: It is not a model to be played with, it is definitely
column2: one piece (build out of 1334 lego-parts) that you will put on&nbsp
column3: display. the designers did not any steering at all to the model, also there are no &quot
column5: included, like in a modular building or a technic-set.

column1: So that'
column2: s why the playability is rated as a 2, because you can admire it, after you are finish building it.

column1: What brings me to fact, why I only rate it at 4 stars: I opened the box, ou comes a bunch of bags and the instructions (printed). Well that'
column3: not unexpected, but the are not somehow logical packed. after the first 3 pages you sit in front of 1.3k parts, all bags open. I did a rough sorting and than I was searching and searching and searching after all. It has many colors and sometimes it is a bit tricky to guess the correct colors. After approx. 4 hours I was finish. I just pulled thru just to get over it. This is one thing, that a downer to me and the reason I rated the building experience only a 3.

column1: I love the model, my kids love it, but this annoying mix of parts in the bags decreases the overall-rating, because
column2: I will for sure remember this exercise in searching, every time I see the model. I&#39
column3: m quite sure, that this model will be a collection item for many people.

,TRUE,5,3,3,2,4 pjgtech","2018-12-29T19:52:11.483Z","VW Camper great kit","

In Red and White, this great Lego model is fantastic fun to build. This was
column4: ve had it on display for about a couple of months.

column1: This set comprises 1334 pieces. The model is approx 300mm long, (12"

This great VW camper (T1) van model features a removable roof section, raising roof section opening front and side doors, opening rear boot, (top and bottom), opening front windows, pull up internal table, moveable "
column3: internal bed / seat, sink, mirror, pot plant, realistic engine bay with engine, rotating wheels with tyres, steering wheel, moveable seat backs, tiled floor, even curtains and a wine glass.

column1: Please note this is an expert level model, so is not recommended for beginners or small children.
This model took me about eight hours to build, but I am no expert, so I'
column2: m sure it could be done a bit faster. The only missing piece as far as I know was&nbsp
column3: the small decorative yellow brush that I see with some other VW Camper models?

I really enjoyed building this great model.
Thanx

,TRUE,5,4,5,5,4 tom_1494","2019-06-09T21:06:37.703Z","Combines a Classic Vehicle with a Modular Building Level of Detail","

I had to buy this Lego set when I saw it online - it looks just like the real thing and has a decent part count for the price.
The only negative I have with this set
column3: s a little bit fiddly to fit properly and can be fragile when you move it once built - apart from that small niggle, this is a fantastic set with an incredible level of detail! I particularly like the curtains and mini kitchen.&nbsp

column1: I enjoyed the interior on this set so much that it actually persuaded me to buy my first modular building (Parisian Restaurant).
Amazing set for the price!

column1:
,TRUE,4,4,5,3,4 GrandInqusitor","2022-07-21T11:26:42.587Z","So few months ago I promised that I will stick to Techinc sets... So as my 5th set","

This VW bus kept calling me to buy it and not a single regret about it now.
Building/Parts:

It was actually pretty fun I like the detail the system building gives instead of technic which is geared more towards to functionality debatable with some sets but let this be argument for different review. Plus lots of little fun details there and there. All the parts were almost new for me as this is my first system set. Of course there are some curtains
column2: and Cloth which are pretty unique to this build it Think. Only thing that is missing is steering.

column1: Aesthetics
Man this is so awesome in aesthetics department. The colour, the shape, and all the moving parts makes this one hell of a display piece giving something extra to every room that you display in it.
Playability
Is it playable: Yes should you buy this a toy for a kid to play: No, there are better options for it. If it had steering it would'
Value for money:
I think this is worth it
Overall
Building this van made
column2: want to take another road trip that I had few years back with RV. I think this is a build that makes you think about camping memories and in the end you have very nice looking display piece. Recommended to all vehicle enthusiasts, camping/RV fans, adult lego fans and lego collectors.
